subtitles.transcript: I don’t go around talking about the fact that we’re in crisis. You know I think there was a crisis.
I don’t think we’re in a crisis. But we are at a time when, you know, we need to debate what –
what the proper sources for funding public higher education should be. And so, you know,
when you have a decision to raise tuition and then you have protests, it feels like a crisis.
But on the other hand, what tends to happen is what’s happening right now.
You have long periods of relative economic prosperity, during which tuition doesn’t go up,
and the moment the the state hits an economic bump, there are problems in the economy generally,
tuition goes up. And that creates another sense of crisis. So you have a political process that is conducive to –
to creating mini-crises that we might not have if we had a certain kind of common understanding
of the fact that it does cost increasing amounts of money every year to fund a great university
and therefore there has to be either greater levels of funding from the state,
greater levels of tuition charged to students, greater success in philanthropy and so on and so forth,
but it’s not that we’re in a crisis. I mean, Berkeley is doing great.
We’re just not fully accepting that if you’re not in crisis, you don’t have needs.
